linkTarget.anchoringText: The A0201 SAP pilot was a single well pair (A01) pilot in the A02 pad of the Christina Lake Thermal Project (CLTP). A map showing the location of the A0201 well pair relative to the neighboring well pairs and pads is shown in Figure 1. The A0201 well pair is drilled 200 meters south of the A0202 well pair which has been on a butane SAP since 2009. The lateral extent of the A0202 chamber is expected to be quite wide and large. The chambers of the two well pairs are expected to be merged by the end of 2017. The geostatistical profile of A0201 well created at the time of drilling is shown in Figure 2.

The A0201 SAP pilot was a single well pair (A01) pilot in the A02 pad of the Christina Lake Thermal Project (CLTP). A map showing the location of the A0201 well pair relative to the neighboring well pairs and pads is shown in Figure 1. The A0201 well pair is drilled 200 meters south of the A0202 well pair which has been on a butane SAP since 2009. The lateral extent of the A0202 chamber is expected to be quite wide and large. The chambers of the two well pairs are expected to be merged by the end of 2017. The geostatistical profile of A0201 well created at the time of drilling is shown in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Geologic Section Along the A0201 Well Pair

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geologic Section Along the A0201 Well Pair

linkTarget.anchoringText: The last 75 meters of the producer well showed high gamma ray values during logging operations and is believed to drilled through shaly structures. The injector well was completed using a single point design with four shiftable steam splitters along the tubing string. A completion diagram of the injector well is shown in Figure 3. Similarly, Figure 4 shows the producer well completion during the circulation. The inner tubing string shown in Figure 4 was pulled out when the well was switched to ESP production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Completion Diagram for A02I01 (the A0201 injector well)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Completion Diagram for A02I01 (the A0201 injector well)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The last 75 meters of the producer well showed high gamma ray values during logging operations and is believed to drilled through shaly structures. The injector well was completed using a single point design with four shiftable steam splitters along the tubing string. A completion diagram of the injector well is shown in Figure 3. Similarly, Figure 4 shows the producer well completion during the circulation. The inner tubing string shown in Figure 4 was pulled out when the well was switched to ESP production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Completion Diagram for A02P01 (the A0201 producer before switching to ESP production)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Completion Diagram for A02P01 (the A0201 producer before switching to ESP production)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The plot of oil production rate, steam injection rate, and SOR for A0201 is shown in Figure 5. The comparison of SAP performance with SAGD production is shown in Figure 6.Figure 5 shows that oil rate during the SAGD period was flat most of the time due to poor conformance with a cold toe in the producer. Figure 6 shows that during the solvent injection period of October 2016 to December 2016, the well pair on average has a 25% oil rate uplift and a 15% SOR reduction though the steam injection rate in SAP is 9%higher than during SAGD.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Oil Production Rates, Steam injection Rates, and SOR for A0201 Well Pair

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Production Rates, Steam injection Rates, and SOR for A0201 Well Pair

linkTarget.anchoringText: The plot of oil production rate, steam injection rate, and SOR for A0201 is shown in Figure 5. The comparison of SAP performance with SAGD production is shown in Figure 6.Figure 5 shows that oil rate during the SAGD period was flat most of the time due to poor conformance with a cold toe in the producer. Figure 6 shows that during the solvent injection period of October 2016 to December 2016, the well pair on average has a 25% oil rate uplift and a 15% SOR reduction though the steam injection rate in SAP is 9%higher than during SAGD.

The presence of the shale barrier is confirmed by a high gamma ray reading in the producer well log. Figure 7 shows the vertical permeability of the simulation model, with the shale barrier identified with very low porosity and permeability in the simulation model. The exact size, porosity and permeability of this shale barrier are unknown; it was found though that in simulation the production performance of the well pair is greatly affected by the size and permeability of the shale barrier.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Vertical permeability in A0201 simulation model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Vertical permeability in A0201 simulation model

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 8 shows the history matched oil production rate. An examination of Figure 8 reveals a strikingly accurate match between the A0201 produced oil rates and the oil production rate from the history matched reservoir model. Figure 9 shows the history matched steam injection rate; the steam injection rate from the history matched simulation model is relatively close to the field data though the match is not accurate as the produced oil rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: History match of SAGD oil production for A0201

formatted-caption.caption-text: History match of SAGD oil production for A0201

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 8 shows the history matched oil production rate. An examination of Figure 8 reveals a strikingly accurate match between the A0201 produced oil rates and the oil production rate from the history matched reservoir model. Figure 9 shows the history matched steam injection rate; the steam injection rate from the history matched simulation model is relatively close to the field data though the match is not accurate as the produced oil rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: History match of SAGD steam injection for A0201

formatted-caption.caption-text: History match of SAGD steam injection for A0201

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 and Figure 11 show the results of different parameter sensitivities on the produced oil rates and injected steam rates respectively. Figure 10 shows the produced oil rates are most impacted by the injected solvent viscosity and solubility, as expected. For example, Figure 10 shows that when the solvent viscosity increased from Realization No. 1 to Realization No. 10, the produced oil rate decreased by about 25 m3/day. Figure 10 and Figure 11 also show that both produced oil rates and injected steam rates are sensitive to how much live steam is produced.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Parameter effect estimation on produced oil rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Parameter effect estimation on produced oil rates

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 10 and Figure 11 show the results of different parameter sensitivities on the produced oil rates and injected steam rates respectively. Figure 10 shows the produced oil rates are most impacted by the injected solvent viscosity and solubility, as expected. For example, Figure 10 shows that when the solvent viscosity increased from Realization No. 1 to Realization No. 10, the produced oil rate decreased by about 25 m3/day. Figure 10 and Figure 11 also show that both produced oil rates and injected steam rates are sensitive to how much live steam is produced.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Parameter effect estimation on injected steam rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Parameter effect estimation on injected steam rates

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 and Figure 13 show the history match results of the early-rise rate SAP test. The history match results give the best matched solvent property values and well constraints and should be used as a starting point in future SAP simulations. It was found that the solvent viscosity correlation from lab data gave the best match while the k-value from the optimal history match case was 90% of the value from the lab correlation. The produced live steam rate in the SAP simulations that gave the best match was 85% of the value used in the SAGD simulations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: History match of SAGD and SAP oil production for A0201

formatted-caption.caption-text: History match of SAGD and SAP oil production for A0201

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 and Figure 13 show the history match results of the early-rise rate SAP test. The history match results give the best matched solvent property values and well constraints and should be used as a starting point in future SAP simulations. It was found that the solvent viscosity correlation from lab data gave the best match while the k-value from the optimal history match case was 90% of the value from the lab correlation. The produced live steam rate in the SAP simulations that gave the best match was 85% of the value used in the SAGD simulations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: History match of SAGD and SAP steam injection for A0201

formatted-caption.caption-text: History match of SAGD and SAP steam injection for A0201
